solution.text:
The total enthalpy change is the sum of the following:
  • Energy change involved in transforming _{j}_ moles of water at _{k}_\(^\circ\)C to _{j}_ moles of water at 0\(^\circ\) C
  • Energy change involved in transforming _{j}_ moles of water at 0\(^\circ\)C to _{j}_ moles of ice at 0\(^\circ\) C
  • Energy change involved in transforming _{j}_ moles of ice at 0\(^\circ \) C to _{j}_ moles of ice at -_{l}_\(^\circ\) C
Note that \(\Delta H_ {freeze} = (-1 \times \Delta H_ {fus})\)
Also remember to convert \(\Delta H_ {freeze}\) to units of \(\frac{J}{mol}\)
Therefore, the total enthalpy change is :
\(\Delta H = No. of\;Moles \times (C_ {p'} \times \Delta T_1 + (-1 \times \Delta H_ {fus} \times 1000) + C_ {p''} \times \Delta T_2)\)
\(\Delta H = _{j}_ \times (75.3 \times (-_{k}_) + 6030 + 36.8 \times (-_{l}_))\)
\(\implies \Delta H = -_{{j*((75.3 * k) + 6030 + (36.8 * l))}}_ \frac{J}{mol}\)
\(\implies \Delta H = -_{{j*((75.3 * k) + 6030 + (36.8 * l))*0.001}}_ \frac{kJ}{mol}\)

What is the enthalpy change on freezing _{j}_ moles of water at _{k}_\(^\circ \) C to ice at negative _{l}_\(^\circ\) C? Use the following data:
\(\Delta_ {fus}H = 6.03 \frac {kJ}{mol} at\;0^{\circ}C\)
\(C_p (H_2O (l)) = C_ {p'}= 75.3 \frac{J}{mol\;K}\)
\(C_p (H_2O (s))= C_ {p''} = 36.8 \frac{J}{mol\;K}\)
